ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: mutual information analyses, behavioral analysis, how to analyze neuroscience papers

Learned how to analyze neural data. Started with learning basic neuroscience and then techniques to analyze spiking data like calculting firing rates (Coefficient variation, binning data), selectivity measures (Tuning curves, Selectivity indices, Area under ROC curve), mutual information (joint prob distributions), ANOVA, PCA...
I learned a lot about computational neuroscience and gained lots of fluency in R coding.
Neural data analysis, niche terminology in neuroscience and how to leverage data science tools for it
Data analysis tools when dealing with neural data.
Learned about applications of data science methods to neuroscience.
I learned a broad variety of statistical techniques (ranging from decoding to PCA to mutual information) and their applications to the neuroscience field.

Multiple computational and statistical methods to analyze large-scale neural recording data.
Hands-on practice on coding.
Collaboration to complete the final project and better understanding of the corresponding data set.
Knowledge about neuroscience and data analysis methods of neuroscience data.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: prof meyers is very nice. i learned a lot of new techniques that i had no experience in before the course, but now feel very confident applying them. my only improvement- my only little thing is that instructions were not always clear - for the final project requirements and for the weekly problem set questions. another strength was the ta, carly, who was very helpful

Strengths: Professor Meyers is super knowledgeable and wants you to succeed. If you're interested in the content, will learn a lot. Final paper where you find your own data to analyze is rewarding. Weakness: high workload (weekly you have to read and answer questions about a neuroscience paper and do a pset), midterm, time consuming final paper. Mix of grad and undergrads in the seminar so if you're an undergrad, can feel overwhelming / intimidating. Basically no guidance for final project. Not a lot of clarity about grading / hard to know where you sit in the class.

As this was the first time the course was being offered, it was a little hard to know what to expect sometimes (in terms of midterm difficulty, final expectations, etc.). That being said, the class was still really well organized and enjoyable.

Strengths- learning about very niche topics in neuroscience
I hope for the future, the course can include more on the coding packages that focus in on specific topics rather than broadly trying to cover everything
Practical and important methods in this field. Inspiring guest lectures. Engaging usual lectures and assignments aligned with weekly readings.
Courseload was manageable and material was interesting. Final project guidelines were incredibly vague; there were barely any.

Strengths: Wide coverage of material, interesting balance between statistics and neuroscience, engaging (yet not too hard) problem sets, final project instead of final exam

Weaknesses: A little bit of a learning curve if you don't know that much about neuroscience, but not too steep
It is a great course. The feedback is always on time.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: i would! lot of helpful techniques, especially if you plan on pursuing neuroscience (or general stats) related research

Yes, if you're interested in the subject. You should probably only take this class if you are an S&DS major or have experience in R. It's also really helpful to have some background / understanding of neuroscience. Don't take the class expecting an easy elective. It's not an extremely hard elective, and it's a seminar which makes it easier to talk to Professor Meyers and stay engaged, but there easier electives and you do have to consistently dedicate time each week to do well.
Yes, as an engaging S&DS elective for thre major.
if you are interested in neuroscience and have a strong foundation in r, then go for it!
Yes. The topics in this course are actually not only for neural data analysis. When applied with care, those methods are suitable for other kinds of data.
Yes, very reasonable and interesting elective. Interesting application of data science methods that are learned in other lower-level courses.

Definitely!! Yale doesn't really have a lot of classes in the S&DS department that allow you to apply statistical methods to a specific subject in detail. Taking this class is a really unique opportunity to see how statistics and data science can drive research in a completely different field. Prof. Meyers does an amazing job showing you how multifaceted the brain can be and how analyzing data from the brain can yield some pretty critical insights. You learn a LOT in the class, and it's one of the best structured (and most interesting) classes I've ever taken. Plus, unlike most S&DS classes, you are pretty much guaranteed to do well if you put in the work as the midterm, problem sets, and final project were pretty fair. Overall, best class in the department so definitely take it if you can!
Yes, it offers updated and practical methods about the field of computational neuroscience.
Yes.
